You should learn multivariable calculus before linear algebra. It's not good to break the continuity of your calculus education. If you are starting to learn calculus from our materials, we recommend you start with Highlights of Calculus by Gil Strang: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBE9407EA64E2C318 to get an overview of calculus. We would then recommend you take 8.01SC Single Variable Calculus: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-01SCF10. We also have an alternative to 8.01, "Calculus Revisited: Single Variable Calculus": http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3B08AE665AB9002A. There are a ton of other excellent materials out there. If these courses do not work for you, do not feel bad or stupid. Try another series and find one that works for you. Best wishes on your studies!

The course textbook: Edwards, Henry C., and David E. Penney. Multivariable Calculus. 6th ed. Lebanon, IN: Prentice Hall, 2002. ISBN: 9780130339676. See http://ocw.mit.edu/18-02F07  for more info. Best wishes on your studies!

I used this to self-learn Vector calculus in my summer finishing year-1 of basic Multi-Calc in college starting from Lesson-15 to Lesson-29. I also made use of Schaum's Vector Analysis for problems and SJ Colley's Vector Calc as an additional reference. I watched all vids in at min 1.25x finishing it up in 2 weeks time.   Dennis Auroux is an absolutely delight and his board-rubbing skills are sooo impressive! His explanations are spectacular & I really enjoyed his emphasis on applications (particularly from physics-inertia, maxwell's eqns etc).  One thing I missed was lack of info on the Frenet-Serret Equations which I found awesome in general & the lack of practicing more problems but hey, you could do both on your own like I did!  Anyways, 12 years after this vid has been released, I'd still recommend this course with all my heart. It is awesome! Thanks MIT for releasing this to the public & thanks Prof. Auroux for just being an amazing lecturer!

There was nothing new that I had learned by watching this, although I did enjoy it very much. The only thing that I noticed about the section that pertains to the dot product that wasn't mentioned but I feel is just as significant is that it doesn't just check for orthogonality whether two vectors are perpendicular or not, but that it also tests if two vectors either coincide or are parallel! They are parallel or coincide when the dot product yields (-1). This is simply because theta will equal either +/- 180 degrees or +/- PI radians where cos(+/- 180) or cos(+/- PI)  yields (-1) because the cosine is an even function.

+B B Yeah, a large part of Calculus 3 - at least the first half - will be about finding volumes between graphs. The typical way to do that it by using so-called double and triple integrals, which sound fancy but they are really just "integrals of integrals". For example, if you have a function that depends on two variables (like z = z(x,y), for example) then a double integral lets you integrate with respect to the first variable (x) while treating y as a constant, and then you integrate that result with respect to y. This is very powerful for finding volumes of 3-dimensional objects, and it's a lot of fun.

Yeah, that's what's so cool about Calculus.  First you learn what derivatives can be used for, then you learn that the derivative of that derivative can be used for a completely different purpose.  Same goes for integrals. Yeah, calculus is a really useful course for a lot of things. As far Calculus 3, I think the best way to imagine that course is that you are simply doing "Calculus 2" in three dimensions. Of course, "Multivariable" really means that you are dealing with "several" variables, but the course tends to stick to a total of 3 variables, since this is possible to actually draw as visual graphs, and everything with a greater number of variables is analogous to 3D graphs anyway. Although some graphs that wouldn't be possible to sketch are still quite intuitive, like for example the temperature T in a room as a function of the x-, y- and z-coordinates could be written as T = T(x,y,z).  I study a 5-year university program called "Engineering Physics & Electrical Engineering", which is probably one of the most advanced engineering programs here (although I think "Space Engineering" is just as advanced). We took "Multivariable Calculus" at the end of our first year, and everything else that year was a lot of physics (largely reviews from high school actually, although slightly more rigorous and with some  new content here and there), linear algebra and single-variable calculus.  One thing that I can recommend is something called "Laplace Transform" - it can seem complicated in the beginning, but it's very straightforward when you have got used to the general idea (it's really just a specific type of integral that lets you transform a function in a very useful way). The Laplace Transform is extremely useful for solving differential equations, since it turns differential equations into algebraic equations, and this can be really useful for Calculus 3 as well. It's certainly not required, but it makes the solution steps to a lot of differential equations much more straightforward.
Thanks, I'll be sure to look that up!  I'm a Computer Science major, so this will probably be my last Calculus class.  After Cal III, I will be taking classes in Discrete Math and Linear Algebra.

+B B I actually remember using some ideas from Linear Algebra in the Multivariable Calculus course that I took - it was something about finding the fundamental matrix for a group of functions (I think it was called the Wronskian), so you might want to check out some basic Linear Algebra right away. It may not be necessary, and your course might introduce the necessary Linear Algebra applications at some point, but it doesn't hurt to come prepared from the start. The "Linear Algebra" videos on Khan Academy are great for that.  One of the simplest applications of Linear Algebra, and the one that's probably easiest to understand, is for solving systems of linear equations, and that's usually one of the first applications that you will see in introductory textbooks. This makes it very easy to solve systems of equations like that, especially on math programs such as MatLab, and you can even do that on most scientific calculators.

L.C L.C Actually, Calculus I & II are primarily single variable.  Calculus I focuses on teaching the concept of derivatives, how to find them, and what they can be used for.  Calculus II focuses on Integrals (the inverse of derivatives...like what division is to multiplication), how to find them, and what they can be used for.  Calculus III uses both concepts to solve multivariable problems.  I haven't taken this one yet, so somebody correct me if I'm wrong.

B B​​  Calculus 3 in a nutshell can be thought of as a multivariable version of Calculus 1 and Calculus 2 - although in reality that course is mostly focused on two variables, such as z = z (x,y), since you can actually sketch and visualise those functions (although you will of course sometimes see more variables than that, like maybe temperature as a function of all three space coordinates T = T(x,y,z), or something like that). But the introduction of several variables also adds some complexity, for example you will be working a lot with partial derivatives and slightly more complex integrals. I guess one way to visually imagine a typical "Calculus 3 scenario" is that you try to find derivatives, tangents, slopes etc of various 3D graphs. Like for example you might have a paraboloid, and then you will be asked to find the slope vector for a particular point on that shape, and so on - and you will also frequently be asked to find the volume under a graph, or even between two intersecting graphs. There will also be a few new useful theorems, such as Green's Theorem, Gauss' Theorem and Stoke's Theorem, which make a lot of things much easier to deal with.

Quanxiang Loo No in reality the geometric expression of dot product is proven by the law of cosines, and the law of cosines has its own proof. He knew that some students hadn't seen the law of cosines before, and they wanted proof that it was correct. So what he did was say that if you just accept that the dot product thing is true, then it can act as a proof of the law of cosines. It was basically a shortcut to save time. It was a bit sloppy and unclear, but he wasn't really saying that the geometric expression of a dot product is really the proof of the law of cosines.

Tensor calculus is really just an extension of vector calculus to higher level mathematical objects; tensors can be visualized as a sort of "array of vectors". Just like vector calculus assigns a vector to every coordinate in the coordinate system and operates on them, tensor calculus assigns tensors to those coordinates. Strictly speaking, a scalar and a vector are both just special low-order tensors, so tensor calculus is really the generalization of single- and multi-variable calculus.

Did you guys know that tangent(t) where (t) is the angle above the horizontal is without a doubt the slope of a line with a linear equation? If we have a line in the form of y = mx+b we know that the slope is defined as m=(y2 - y1)/(x2 - x1) which is also (dy/dx). We can see that this is the rate of change in y to rate of change in x. So we can substitute this as sin(t)/cos(t) which also equals tan(t). We can take our original equation and convert it to y = tan(t)x + b. And this is just the introduction to how we go from a rate of change in linear equations to those of curves when we find a point on that curve that has a line that is tangent to it. Without the law of Cosines we and the applications of limits we wouldn't be able to differentiate! Everything I mentioned above and more is all embedded in the simplest of all expressions... (1+1). Consider 1 to be a unit vector that has + direction and a magnitude of 1. What happens when we apply the arithmetic addition operation of a vector to itself? We are applying a linear transformation which is typically called translation! It is also evident that there is perfect symmetry, reflection, and rotation in the expression (1+1).  And I have only involved an expression here not even an equation or a function! Everything in mathematics is embedded in 1+1 including negation, multiplication, division, exponentiation, roots, logarithms, vector notations, matrices, algebra, geometry, trigonometry, and calculus. Math is simple when you understand that everything is built off of something simpler. Just like in computer hardware engineering to software engineering, there are layers of abstraction!

For any vector v with components x, y, z, the dot product between v and vector A(1, 2, 3) is always 0. So, they are penpendiculat to each other. This means that all possible vectors v( x, y, z) defines a plane, in other wods, all points x, y, z are in a unique plane.

Think this way. Vector A(1, 2, 3) is constant, so it points in some direction in space. All vector v(x, y, z) must be perpendicular to vector A because the dot product between A and v is 0. So, all vectors v (infinite number of points x, y, z) fill a plane in space and this plane is perpendicular to vector A.
